recent_posts.title: BIP-352 Silent Payments addresses should have an expiration time
recent_posts.summary:
- Wallets can lose or be compromised, leading to addresses becoming toxic data.
- Silent Payments addresses should eventually expire to maintain privacy and prevent loss of funds.
- Adding a 3-byte field encoding the expiration date would solve this problem.

recent_posts.title: Announcing Libforesta
recent_posts.summary:
- Davidson Souza has developed `libfloresta`, a compact, Utreexo-powered Bitcoin full node with integrated wallet.
- The project is written in Rust and has bindings to run virtually anywhere through WebAssembly.
- Floresta is currently available on Davidson's GitHub page and aims to be user-friendly on low-power devices.

recent_posts.title: BIP352: Silent Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- The BIP for Silent Payments has undergone review and revision, including changes to key types, versioning scheme, and address encoding.
- The specification provides guidelines for scanning transactions, shared secret derivation, sender actions, and receiver actions.
- Silent payments is a protocol introducing a new address format and protocol for sending Bitcoin transactions, focusing on privacy and usability.

recent_posts.title: Jamming Mitigation Dry Run
recent_posts.summary:
- The ideal data collection period is limited to 6 months, providing aggregated results to node operators.
- Data sharing will follow best practices and anonymization, addressing concerns about re-identification and timestamps.
- Trust and transparency are crucial; time-boxed collection, data storage, and access need clarification.

recent_posts.title: Multipath Keysend
recent_posts.summary:
- ZmnSCPxj proposed a scheme for a `keysend` protocol that enables multipath payments.
- The scheme involves embedding a preimage in the `keysend` and generating a payment hash.
- The receiver can claim the payment once all parts of the `keysend` have arrived.

recent_posts.title: Specification Meeting Transcripts
recent_posts.summary:
- Our team has been recording and transcribing specification meetings every other Monday.
- Transcripts of these meetings are now available at [https://btctranscripts.com/lightning-specification].
- Gurwinder from Chaincode ensured the accuracy of these transcripts, maintaining the highest quality recordings.

active_posts.title: Blinded 2-party Musig2
active_posts.summary:
- The implementation discusses a version of 2-of-2 Schnorr Musig2 for statechains.
- Party 1 needs to be fully 'blinded', not learning certain information like aggregate public key or message being signed.
- Blinding for Party 1 involves specific steps for key and nonce aggregation performed by Party 2.

active_posts.title: Pull-req to enable Full-RBF by default
active_posts.summary:
- The author has submitted a pull request to enable full-replace-by-fee (full-rbf) by default in Bitcoin Core.
- Various block explorers and nodes have already enabled full-rbf, indicating its popularity.
- The author proposes enabling full-rbf by default in an upcoming release and removing the BIP125 code.

active_posts.title: Concern about "Inscriptions".
active_posts.summary:
- I am concerned about a bug that has been overlooked in recent Bitcoin software versions.
- The bug involves rapidly growing "inscriptions" that cause issues with the UTXO set.
- I urge Bitcoin developers to consider implementing a feature to reject these inscriptions.

active_posts.title: Potential vulnerability in Lightning backends: BOLT-11 "payment hash" does not commit to payment!
active_posts.summary:
- LNbits team discovered an exploit allowing attackers to create balances by exploiting invoice handling.
- LNbits version 0.10.5 has fixed the exploit and users are urged to update.
- Attack raises awareness about similar exploits in Lightning applications and highlights necessary precautions.

active_posts.title: LN Summit 2023 Notes
active_posts.summary:
- The annual specification meeting was held in New York City in late June.
- Attendees attempted to take transcript-style notes, which can be found at the provided link.
- Gratitude was expressed towards those who attended the meeting and the event hosts. Michael Levin was thanked for assisting with note-taking.

active_posts.title: Blinded Paths Doom Scenario
active_posts.summary:
- Blinded paths in the Lightning Network offer privacy benefits for receiving nodes.
- Payments can only be made through given paths, potentially leading to centralization.
- There are concerns about compromising sender-side privacy and pressure from "chain analysis" companies.
